title: Great British Bake off recipes: Is a Madeira cake or creme brûlée more energy efficient?
text:
Great British Bake off recipes: Is a Madeira cake or creme brûlée more energy efficient? Great British Bake off recipes: Is a Madeira cake or creme brûlée more energy efficient? THE Great British Bake Off final this Wednesday is expected to create a power surge at the National Grid as fans tune in to see who is crowned champion - but do you know which recipe takes the highest toll on your energy bill? PUBLISHED: 17:49, Mon, Oct 5, 2015 | UPDATED: 18:21, Mon, Oct 5, 2015 GETTY A Maderia cake is one of the most expensive recipes to bake 
During last year's final of the show demand for energy jumped as viewers watched - and perhaps even baked along.The popular show has inspired one out of four fans to try recipes at home- but there is a large difference in how much the creations add to bills, according to a survey by British Gas. The Madeira cake from episode one is the most popular 'have a go' bake and with an oven time of one hour, it costs around 28p in energy. But the three-tiered cheese cake is by far the most expensive recipe in terms of energy with a baking time of two and a half hours that costs around 70p.Soda bread and crème brûlée are the second and third spots respectively, found British Gas.The two recipes cost 16p and 21p respectively in terms of baking times. Cream horns and baguettes and chocolate tarts take the least amount of time in the oven, coming in at just 5p and 9p. British Gas Cheese cakes and Maderia cakes cost the most to bake GETTY Mary Berry will crown the winnner of Bake Off 2015 on Wednesday Related articles When will UK families benefit? Energy giants blasted over failure... 
Sarah Scrivener, smart energy expert at British Gas, said: “The majority of Bake Off recipes cost less than 30p to cook in the oven. "Whether you’re a beginner baker or a whizz in the kitchen, understanding how much it costs to cook can be really useful - as well as knowing things that can save energy like turning the oven off five minutes before the end of your cooking time.“If you have smart meters, you can check your in-home display which shows you how much energy is being used in near real-time, in pounds and pence."
